M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a728.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this Court issued the original custody order on May 15, 2020, and both parties and the minor children continue to reside within Middlesex County.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a76.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this Court issued the original custody order on May 15, 2020, and both parties and the minor children continue to reside within Middlesex County.

Mass. Gen. Laws c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The Plaintiff satisfies the burden of showing a material change warranting modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28 and Mass. Gen. Laws c. 208, § 31 (defining custody and parental responsibilities), and seeks an order aligning the parenting schedule with the current realities of the Defendant’s work schedule and the children’s welfare.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that custody and parenting orders are subject to modification where substantial changes affect the child’s welfare.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial divorce judgment involving custody and a removal request, not modification of an existing custody or parenting order. The court discusses standards for awarding custody and permitting removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, but nowhere addresses when or how custody or parenting orders may later be modified due to substantial changes. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition about long‑recognized modifiability of custody orders upon substantial change in circumstances.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt:
“Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… .”

(This passage addresses removal standards, not modification of existing custody orders.)

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that custody and parenting orders are subject to modification where substantial changes affect the child’s welfare.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for making and explaining an initial custody award in the context of domestic violence, not with modification of existing custody or parenting orders based on a substantial change in circumstances. Nowhere does the court discuss the modifiability of custody judgments or articulate the “substantial change affecting the child’s welfare” standard. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts have long recognized that custody and parenting orders are subject to modification when substantial changes affect the child’s welfare.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Rosenberg v. Rosenberg, 33 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Rosenberg v. Rosenberg, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (1992)
Rosenberg v. Rosenberg, 33 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that custody and parenting orders are subject to modification where substantial changes affect the child’s welfare.
Rosenberg v. Rosenberg, 33 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with alimony and property division under G.L. c. 208, § 34, not custody or parenting orders. The only mention of modification concerns potential future modification of alimony if the husband’s income changes, and the court expressly contrasts that with the non-modifiability of property division; it does not address custody or parenting arrangements at all. Therefore it does not support the proposition about modification of custody and parenting orders.
Rosenberg v. Rosenberg, 33 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: "Alimony awards have the advantages of tax benefits to the paying spouse and flexibility, should the financial circumstances of either spouse change substantially. By contrast, a division of capital assets, absent fraud, is not subject to later modification. Kirtz v. Kirtz, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 141, 148 (1981)."

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: The Court in Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981) held that modification is justified when the custodial arrangement no longer meets the child’s best interests due to unforeseen circumstances.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The case concerns a custodial parent’s request for permission to remove children from Massachusetts under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a post‑judgment modification of an existing custody order due to unforeseen circumstances. The Appeals Court reverses because the probate judge failed to consider all relevant best‑interest factors—particularly the welfare of the custodial parent and alternative visitation arrangements. It does not articulate any requirement that modification is justified only when an existing custodial arrangement no longer meets the child’s best interests due to unforeseen circumstances; rather, it prescribes the factors to be weighed in an initial or contemporaneous removal decision.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice… on the parent having the primary responsibility for the day-to-day care of the children.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Factors relevant to the best interests of the child include stability, parental availability, and continuity of care.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses that a core aspect of the best-interests analysis is preserving stable, continuous caregiving arrangements and avoiding unnecessary disruption of a satisfactory status quo. It emphasizes stability, continuity with the primary caregiver, and the parents’ respective work schedules and availability in determining where the child should reside during school weeks and weekends. While it does not list “continuity of care” and “parental availability” as a formal test, those concepts are central to the reasoning about the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “These efforts also reflect the view that it is in the ‘best interests of the child’ to preserve the current placement with a parent, if it is a satisfactory one, and that stability and continuity with the child’s primary caregiver is itself an important factor in a child’s successful upbringing. … If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child….”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Changes in parental employment affecting a parent’s ability to maintain parenting time may constitute a material change.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses relocation and relies on the ALI Principles § 2.17, which it quotes as stating that relocation of a parent "constitutes a substantial change in circumstances" when it significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities under the judgment. That directly links changes in a parent’s situation (here, relocation associated with work/life circumstances) that affect the ability to maintain parenting time to a material change. Although the case is about relocation rather than employment per se, it treats a major life change impacting the exercise of parenting responsibilities as a qualifying substantial/material change.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] ...”
...
“(4)(c) If neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility for the child, the court should modify the plan ... in accordance with the child’s best interests, taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Changes in parental employment affecting a parent’s ability to maintain parenting time may constitute a material change.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with initial custody determinations and emphasizes that all relevant factors must be weighed in light of the child’s best interests. It does not discuss modifications based on changed circumstances, parental employment, or parenting time. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that changes in parental employment affecting parenting time constitute a material change.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 556 n.5 (1980). The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: A parent’s delegation of overnight care to non‑parent individuals without agreement may justify modification when it interferes with stability.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address a parent’s delegation of overnight care to non‑parent individuals as a basis for modification, nor does it suggest that such delegation, without agreement, justifies modifying custody when it interferes with stability. Instead, the court reverses a change of custody, emphasizing that no material and substantial change in circumstances occurred and criticizing the trial judge’s reliance on a temporary, court‑imposed change and the child’s extended‑family contacts. The case thus undercuts, rather than supports, the idea that such caregiving arrangements justify modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification. … Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement.”

Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).proposition: The Court’s primary concern remains the best interests and welfare of the children.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the constitutional and statutory requirement of parental unfitness and the specific psychological impact on this child, and it discusses weighing the mature child’s preferences. While the court clearly considers the child’s welfare and emotional development, it does not expressly articulate a broad, general principle that the court’s primary concern in such cases is always the best interests and welfare of the children. The case is framed more in terms of parental unfitness and risk of serious harm rather than a generic ‘best interests’ standard as the primary concern, so using it for that broad proposition is somewhat overstated.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “A finding of parental unfitness may be predicated on the circumstances within a particular family, as they adversely affect the particular child, without regard to the general quality of parental conduct per se. ‘It is not the quality or character of parental conduct per se that justifies State intervention on behalf of an abused, neglected, or otherwise endangered child. Rather, it is the fact of the endangerment itself. As parens patriae the State does not act to punish misbehaving parents; rather it acts to protect endangered children.’”
